issue.title: Provide an ADR explaining difference between Configuration and Service

milestone.title: v2.0.0 Release
milestone.description: These are features that are useful or important but would result in an API break requiring a new major version to release.

issue.title: Reconsider JSON serialization format

milestone.title: v2.0.0 Release
milestone.description: These are features that are useful or important but would result in an API break requiring a new major version to release.

issue.body:
It would be helpful to support functionality out-of-the-box that is currently not easily accomplished. The `Psr\Log\LoggerAwareInterface` is a type that should be able to be prepared without registering as an explicit service. This is currently not possible. If you want to prepare this type you MUST also define it as an explicit service.

 It is unlikely that you'd actually want to get an instance of a `LoggerAwareInterface` from a Container and having this in the container as a service seems off. We should consider how the serializer formats itself to not have this requirement.

issue.title: Merge XmlSerializer into ContainerDefinitionSerializer

milestone.title: v1.6 Release
milestone.description: This release will only include deprecations leading up to 2.0.

issue.body: Annotated Container should only implement and support 1 serialization format. That format should be the XmlSerializer being implemented in #139. When that work is done the ContainerDefinitionSerializer interface can be refactored to a single class that implements a known serialization format. This is specifically useful for the work that will be done on #47 where having a known serialization format will be helpful as non-PHP code will have to interact with it and cannot rely on deserializing the ContainerDefinition.

issue.title: Deprecate JsonContainerDefinitionSerializer

milestone.title: v1.6 Release
milestone.description: This release will only include deprecations leading up to 2.0.

issue.body:
The existing JSON serialization has various issues with the format and needs to be updated to include support for serializing Inject values correctly. In addition, a new XML serializer format is being implemented that can replace the JSON format for caching purposes and is meant to be suitable for uses in static analysis contexts.

It doesn't really make sense for us to provide multiple serialization formats. Serializing a ContainerDefinition is complicated and having multiple implementations is most likely going to lead to pain. Because the XML serializer solves problems that exists in the JSON serializer and will provide other functionality it does not make sense to offer both.

issue.title: Provide more details on expected implementation of custom attributes
Add a method on each definition that returns ?ObjectType<Attribute>

milestone.title: v2.0.0 Release
milestone.description: These are features that are useful or important but would result in an API break requiring a new major version to release.

issue.body:
There might be reasons for a definition to need to know what attribute was used for reasons other than just creating the container. We should expose, at the minimum, which Attribute type was used to determine the definition. Since it might be possible for a definition to come from the functional API we should also account for it being null.

This would represent a significant change to existing interfaces that this requires a major version release.

comment.body: Thinking about this some more just an Attribute type isn't sufficient. The `InjectAttribute` is expected to be repeatable. Not only would you need the Attribute but you'd need the index for the specific usage as well. It might be better to allow access to the Attribute instance itself.

issue.title: Introduce facade for simplified user API

milestone.title: v2.0.0 Release
milestone.description: These are features that are useful or important but would result in an API break requiring a new major version to release.

issue.body:
> Please note that this is not a Laravel Facade, but an implementation of the [classic OOP design pattern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facade_pattern).

For end-users to actually get their AnnotatedContainer (the piece they most care about) there are 2 subsystems they MUST interact with and another that they are likely to interact with.

- A `ContainerDefinitionCompiler` through the `compiler()` function
- A `ContainerFactory` through the `containerFactory()` function
- A `AnnotatedContainerEmitter` through the `eventEmitter()` function

These interactions are relatively complex from and end-user's perspective. In addition there are problems with the `eventEmitter()` function relying on a static variable to keep a reference to the event emitter. In addition to this the `eventEmitter()`, and all its listeners, sticking around represents something of a memory leak. The AnnotatedContainer event system is _not_ your app's event system and is meant to be limited in scope. Ideally after the Container is created the emitter, and all the listeners, should be destroyed to allow GC to clear up the memory used.

Implementing a facade that provides a single entrypoint for all these interactions could make the DX better and clear up problems with the static state in `eventEmitter()` by removing the need to have a global function. Instead you'd add the listeners directly to the facade which would be responsible for the event emitter's lifecycle.

issue.title: RFC: Add start() and stop() methods to HttpServer interface (v3+)
issue.body:
I'm digging into the 3.0 beta and from a testing perspective I appreciate the HttpServer interface. It allows to more easily write unit tests in addition to integration tests. However, this interface does not include methods to start and stop the server, limiting its usefulness from a testing perspective.

Are the maintainers open to including the existing start() and stop() methods on the `SocketHttpServer` in the `HttpServer` interface?

comment.body: @kelunik FWIW the code that has the HttpServer injected is also the code that "owns" the instance. I'm wrapping some other events, route autowiring, and middleware setup before the server itself actually starts. In effect, I want you to be able to bootstrap a Container, get my `Application` class that wraps all that stuff, and then call `$app->start()`.

milestone.title: v2.0.0 Release
milestone.description: These are features that are useful or important but would result in an API break requiring a new major version to release.

issue.title: Organize classes into better namespaces

milestone.title: v2.0.0 Release
milestone.description: These are features that are useful or important but would result in an API break requiring a new major version to release.

issue.body: Our current organizational structure isn't scalable and makes it hard to look through the codebase at times. We should organize the code into more descriptive namespaces. We should ensure that a `class_alias` to the existing class name is created for the new class name.

commits.message:
Feature/namespace organization (#221)

* Move definitions and builder to namespace

* Move events into namespace

* Move containerfactory into namespace

* Add compile namespace

* Add AliasResolution namespace

* Move container builder context to Compile namespace

* Add bootstrap namespace

* Add Serializer namespace

* add profiles namespace

* Add Autowire namespace, move converter to Compile namespace

* Move SupportedContainers enum to ContainerFactory

* Move SupportedContainers enum to ContainerFactory

* Move HasBackingContainer method into AnnotatedContainer

* Run v2 PRs on CI
